review.title: Cognitive Systems and Question Answering
review.abstract: This paper briefly characterizes the field of cognitive computing. As an exemplification, the field of natural language question answering is introduced together with its specific challenges. A possibility to master these challenges is illustrated by a detailed presentation of the LogAnswer system, which is a successful representative of the field of natural language question answering.

metadata.title: Cognitive Systems and Question Answering

sections.text: Human computer interaction is a discipline of increasing importance. Many people spend a lot of time with computers that play games, watch movies, but of course also solve problems during their professional activity. This becomes all the more important as more data and information has to be taken into account. In fact, this amount is increasing every day. Big data and open data are keywords that refer to areas of computer science in which exactly these aspects are tackled. This paper briefly describes the term cognitive computing and shows that answering natural language questions is an example of this new computer paradigm. In the next section, cognitive computing is discussed, followed by a brief overview of answering natural language questions, then the LogAnswer system is described, and finally we conclude with current enhancements and future work.

sections.heading: Cognitive Computing
sections.text: In terms of the development of intelligent machines, IBM has twice succeeded in setting a milestone: in 1997, the chess computer Deep Blue succeeded in beating the world champion Garry Kasparov. After this match, there was a discussion about whether the IBM team cheated during the tournament. Kasparov demanded revenge, which was refuted, and, even more, Deep Blue was dismantled. In 2011, the IBM computer system Watson beat two former winners in the quiz show Jeopardy. In Jeopardy, players must understand natural language questions from different areas and give quick answers. This type of question answering and reasoning is called deep answer to questions. The Watson system used many different sources of knowledge. Watson had no connection to the Internet, Watson had access to databases, dictionaries, encyclopedias, ontologies, but also literary ontologies and newspaper articles.

sections.heading: Natural Language Question-Answering
sections.text: Until the 1980s, most systems that process natural language were based on explicit, hand-encoded rules that analyzed the syntactical structure of sentences or dependence on semantic components, where utterances were understood to have a syntax characterized by formal grammar, especially context-free grammar. Later, syntactic rules were reinforced by descriptions of syntactical components, such as grammars or semantic networks [5]. These representations can also be expressed through logical formulas that lead to so-called phrase-structure grammars.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: As a prototype example, the LogAnswer system is described in detail and its properties are checked against criteria for cognitive computer systems. Currently, the LogAnswer system is being expanded in the follow-up project RatioLog, which aims at the inclusion of rational and human-like argumentation components. One of the latest and most prominent theories in this respect is HPSG – Head-Driven Phrase Structure Grammar [8].
Hidden Markov Models were used to predict which word or part of speech is used next [7].
LogAnswer [2] is an open domain question answering system.

In the LogAnswer system NLP is used to filter the input for the theorem prover to a fraction of the knowledge available to LogAnswer, and the prover is embedded into a relaxation mechanism which can lessen the proof requirements for imperfect input data [3].

One part of the knowledge is provided by a snapshot of the German Wikipedia, which has been translated into a semantic network representation in the MultiNet (Multilayered Extended Semantic Networks) formalism [5].
See [3] for details on the translation of the MultiNet knowledge base into a first-order logic knowledge base.
In the next step the theorem prover Hyper [9] is used.
The Hyper theorem prover is an implementation of the hypertableaux calculus [1] extended with equality.
In [4] the use of deontic logic for modeling human reasoning and its automating with the logical machinery from LogAnswer is demonstrated.
Another extension is with respect to defeasible reasoning [11], which is helpful to determine the best answer from the possibly contradicting answer candidates.
